ranked_diseases.explanation: All three reference cases with nearly identical phenotypic features (B lymphocytopenia, decreased class-switched memory B cells, hypogammaglobulinemia, recurrent sinusitis, poor vaccine response) were diagnosed with CVID13. The patient's phenotype matches perfectly with the core features.

CVID1 presents with similar humoral immunodeficiency features including hypogammaglobulinemia, B cell abnormalities, and recurrent sinopulmonary infections. The phenotype is consistent though less specific than CVID13.

CVID2 shares the core features of B cell dysfunction, reduced immunoglobulins, and recurrent infections. The specific pattern of decreased class-switched memory B cells is characteristic of various CVID subtypes.
CVID8 (LRBA deficiency) can present with similar B cell abnormalities and hypogammaglobulinemia, though often has additional autoimmune features not present in this patient.
PIK3R1 deficiency causes B cell lymphopenia and agammaglobulinemia with recurrent infections. However, the presence of some immunoglobulin production makes this less likely than CVID.
ORAI1 deficiency can cause combined immunodeficiency with B cell dysfunction and hypogammaglobulinemia, though typically presents earlier in life with more severe manifestations.
